p: Some modeling studies have shed light on the transmission dynamics of COVID-19 at the population level [8], [43], [44], [45], [46], [47], [48], [49]. However, the within-host viral dynamics of SARS-CoV-2 infection have not been quantitatively investigated. Here we use mathematical models to study the pathogenic characteristics of SARS-CoV-2 infection by examining the interaction between viral replication and the host immune responses. We fit models to available data of SARS-CoV-2 infected patients and non-human primates in different countries [14], [50], [51], [52]. We also use model simulations to evaluate some potential therapies against COVID-19. Combination of antiviral drugs and type I interferon (IFN) may control the SARS-CoV-2 replication. This is consistent with the observation that SARS-CoV-2 is sensitive to IFN [53]. These findings may provide new insights into the pathogenesis of SARS-CoV-2 infection and development of new treatment strategies.
